bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George E. Armstrong, September 10, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Armstrong that he has not heard from Nogueira. Hench hopes that Armstrong can come to the dedication of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George E. Armstrong, September 10, 1952
div1.p:
September 10, 1952 REF: MEDDA
619.3 (Camp Lazear) C
Major General George E. Armstrong
The Surgeon General
Department of the Army
Washington 25, D. C.

Thank you very kindly for your official and personal letters of August 22
regarding the proposed dedication of Camp Lazear by the Cuban Government.

I have had no further information from Dr. Pedro Nogueira. That is quite
characteristic of my Cuban correspondence. I have sent to Doctor Nogueira
an osalid copy of your “official” letter of August 22 and have gently
urged him to send invitations not only to you and the State Department
but also to General Reed and others at their early convenience if their
plans for dedicating Camp Lazear at the end of this month are still in
order.

I do hope that you may yourself be able to attend the dedication but I am
sure that if you cannot the presence of Major General Paul H. Streit will
be greatly appreciated by all concerned.

Thank you very much for sending me the list of the names of the volunteers
with the middle names, which list I understand constitutes the official
spelling of these names. I have forwarded this to Doctor Nogueira. I
note, however, that the middle name of James Hanberry, on the list which
you sent me, is spelled Lanard. I am sure this is wrong as he himself
signs his name James Leonard Hanberry. May I suggest that this correction
be made as is necessary.

Sincerely yours,
P. S. Hench, M.D.
